author: _shemnon
content:
> See ProgPoW where audits were demanded,
The algorithm it was replacing, Ethash, received a similar audit.  So even if the goal wasn't to try and stop ProgPoW the call for an audit was still the correct move.  IMHO if the only goal was to block it there would have been an insistence that the GitCoin grant was the only source to pay for the audit.

author: holiman
content:
<@!381789485777682434> no.. You need to have at least some idea about whether you want to benchmark block imports, or evm performance, or disk access... If it's pure "generic" evm, we sometimes check with a 'snailtracer',which is basically a very old raytracer converted to bytecode. I'm not sure what the bulk of the ops are, but there's quite a lot of arithmetics and general looping, pushing etc, probably not so much precompile usage, but I'm not sure
```
./build/bin/evm --statdump -codefile snailtracer.hex run 1>/dev/null 
EVM gas used:    305382972
execution time:  318.692387ms
allocations:     1661
allocated bytes: 56905160
```
The bytecode is here: https://gist.github.com/karalabe/dc2fd6add66341c60e7cc96b91ba0f76

author: chfast
content: It is dominated by mod operations.

author: shamatar
content: I‚Äôve indeed wanted to test the EVM. 30 minutes of profiling and optimizations have allowed me to get staticcall to around 22 gas on Geth using Martin‚Äôs testing approach. It does not break any Geth tests (not state tests, didn‚Äôt try them), but I want to check if it affects broad EVM performance in general
